meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>original</radical> <radical>geoduck</radical> had a <kanji>request</kanji>. He wants there to be more geoducks in the world!
The <radical>leader</radical> of the <radical>yakuza</radical> shows you his <radical>knife</radical>. He says, "This is an <kanji>example</kanji> of a knife."

You give a <radical>lid</radical> to a <radical>person</radical> (two of them, in fact), then they put it on a <radical>cross</radical> when you <kanji>graduate</kanji>. It's a symbolic ceremony, putting a lid over a cross, but it's just what you do when you graduate around these parts.

Next to the <radical>cross</radical> we combine our <radical>power</radical> <radical>power</radical> <radical>power</radical> so that we have <kanji>cooperation</kanji>. And with our powers combined, we become stronger than we ever could have been apart, lifting the cross above our heads!

You try to be <radical>private</radical>, but because of your <radical>big</radical> <radical>hair</radical> you end up having to <kanji>participate</kanji> in everything. Can you imagine people asking for volunteers or something, and you trying to look inconspicuous with your big hair? Of course they're going to notice you and make you participate.
The <radical>circumference</radical> radical and the <kanji>circumference</kanji> kanji are the same!

The <radical>mouth</radical> of a <radical>well</radical> will <kanji>surround</kanji> you if you fall into it. The mouth of a well is the opening of the well, and if you fall into that well, the mouth as well as the rest of the well will surround you.
A <radical>mouth</radical> that is <radical>old</radical> is going to be <kanji>hard</kanji>.
A <radical>grain</radical>'s <radical>child</radical> will grow with the <kanji>seasons</kanji>. In spring the grain is born, it grows in summer, is harvested in fall, and dies in winter.

The <radical>roof</radical> that became the <radical>origin</radical> of all roofs was <kanji>perfect</kanji>. It was tall and wide so it could fit and protect everyone. And the dimensions were perfect too.
There is a <radical>treasure</radical> on top of a <radical>narwhal</radical> who wears a <radical>towel</radical> that will grant your greatest <kanji>wish</kanji>.

If you live in the <radical>now</radical>, there’s a good chance your <radical>heart</radical> controls your <kanji>thought</kanji> process. You don’t have time to think with your brain, you need an answer now so you use your heart to make decisions and thought process.

If your <radical>fingers</radical> are strong enough, you can take an <radical>axe</radical> and <kanji>fold</kanji> it in half. But be careful not to <kanji>bend</kanji> it too far, or you might just <kanji>break</kanji> it!

Causing <radical>death</radical> at every turn, the <radical>moon</radical> <radical>king</radical> sits inside his moon, getting ready to cause death on anything in his sights. Sounds a lot like the Death Star from a certain movie. One of which is "Star Wars: A New <kanji>Hope</kanji>."

A <radical>tree</radical> with <radical>talent</radical> can become <kanji>lumber</kanji>. Not all trees can do this. Only the talented ones are able to turn themselves into lumber or <kanji>material</kanji>, to be used for a million different things.
The <radical>bundle</radical> radical and the <kanji>bundle</kanji> kanji are the same!
When climbing a <radical>tree</radical> in <radical>public</radical>, it’s best to choose a <kanji>pine</kanji>. Pine trees offer the most coverage, so you’ll be able to hide, even out in public.
<radical>Yakuza</radical> <radical>bars</radical> barely exist. The <kanji>remainder</kanji> of them aren't even in Japan.

A <radical>white</radical> guy jumps into a <radical>pool</radical> with a <kanji>target</kanji> painted on the bottom. He's aiming for the target, of course.

This kanji can also mean <kanji>-al</kanji>, as in the endings you get on some English adjectives. You know, like the pool is artifici-al. Or painting a target down there is not practic-al. That kind of -al.

You tie a <radical>thread</radical> on your finger before jumping in the <radical>pool</radical> to remind yourself of the <kanji>promise</kanji> you made to your mother. The thread represents the promise you made to mow the lawn after you finished swimming in the pool.
You put <radical>flowers</radical> on a <radical>cloud</radical> and call it <kanji>art</kanji>. Not everyone agrees that your flower cloud art is actually art, but you know it is.

<radical>Crab</radical>s in the <radical>dirt</radical> make a great <kanji>foundation</kanji> for a seaside hut. It's right on the seashore, where all the crabs dig their holes in the dirt. But as they get old and die, their bodies form a strong base. Perfect for the foundation of a building like this!

Everyone has a <radical>soul</radical> in their <radical>life</radical>, and that soul shapes their <kanji>gender</kanji>. It's not just about body parts — it's about what's inside. In the end, it's one's <kanji> nature</kanji> that truly matters.

If a <radical>tree</radical> wants to <radical>kiss</radical> you, it's a sign of your <kanji>status</kanji>. Only someone of high status would be worthy enough to receive the gnarly but gentle kiss of a tree. Trees don't kiss just anyone, you know.

In a <radical>private</radical> place on the <radical>moon</radical>, you hide two <radical>spoon</radical>s that give you a special <kanji>ability</kanji>. It's the ability to predict the future! The private moon spoons reflect the knowledge of time and space into your brain. Now that's a cool ability!

If you have a <radical>mustache</radical> and you hit your <radical>forehead</radical> on the <radical>moon</radical>, you’re probably going to break a <kanji>bone</kanji>. Ok, so it doesn’t matter so much if you have a mustache, but if you’re travelling fast enough to make it to the moon, you’re definitely breaking a bone if you run into it.

A <radical>cleat</radical>-wearing <radical>woman</radical> is walking on someone's back, but she doesn't want to hurt him, so she has to be very <kanji>gentle</kanji>. Cleats are sharp and pointy, and not designed for back-walking, so she's being extra gentle right now.

<radical>Rain</radical> makes up one <radical>part</radical> of this, and the rest is air or something. I imagine this is what people thought the <kanji>atmosphere</kanji> was made out of thousands of years ago.

The <radical>origin</radical> of the <radical>geoduck</radical> is a pretty <kanji>stubborn</kanji> one. The geoduck race is so stubborn that it refused to evolve into an animal that made any sense. Hence, the origin of the geoduck is one of stubbornness.

The <radical>gate</radical> to <radical>talent</radical> is now <kanji>closed</kanji>. In fact, the gate to talent is always closed. It's not like anyone can just waltz in and get themselves some talent. You have to work for it! You have to work hard to get through that closed gate to talent!
The <radical>well</radical> radical and the <kanji>well</kanji> kanji are the same.

The best kind of flowers to grow in your window? Strawberry, obviously. Yes, there are strawberry flowers — it's actually the flowers that turn into the strawberries, you know. And they're perfect as window flowers because they need a ton of light. That's why all your window flowers are strawberries.
One <radical>animal</radical> that is particularly  <radical>good</radical> is the <kanji>wolf</kanji>. Wolves have a bad reputation, but actually they're very, very good animals.
